author: ljani
body:
# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
# Go to home, be logged into Windows as a domain user
cd
New-Item -Type Directory mytest
cd .\mytest\
$acl = Get-Acl -Path .
# NB. the user nor MYCOMPUTER does not exist
$rule = New-Object System.Security.AccessControl.FileSystemAccessRule("MYCOMPUTER\mylocaluser", "FullControl", "None", "None", "Allow")
# NB. The following command will throw an error and it's expected
$acl.AddAccessRule($rule)
# In some variations only Set-Acl will throw the error
Set-Acl -Path . -AclObject $acl

# This is where everything breaks when you query for ACLs again:
Get-Acl .
```

# Expected behavior

```
    Directory: C:\Users\myuser


Path   Owner        Access
----   -----        ------
thesis MYDOMAIN\myuser NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM Allow  FullControl...
```

# Actual behavior

```none
    Directory: C:\Users\myuser


Path   Owner Access
----   ----- ------
mytest
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.2.0-preview.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.2.0-preview.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

Thanks.

EDIT: Updated to reflect the weird `Get-Acl` behavior. Sorry for the mess, I wish I could delete my issue.
